(Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First Year Students Only)
(Entry level seminar focusing on a specific topic. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.)
(The IMF estimated that by 2019, India will be the world's fastest growing economy. With 29 states and seven union territories, 20-plus officially recognized languages and over 200 local dialects, an economic growth rate of 7.4% this year and the world's largest "demographic dividend," India also has a robust and growing media system with many regional vernacular outlets, and a complex array of regional political parties. As background to discussing present day issues and institutions, India's fall festival season and The Carlos Museum together present a unique opportunity for cultural learning.)
Students will visit the South Asia collection at The Carlos Museum, discuss key concepts from the writings of 19th and 20th century Indian philosophers, and learn to analyze news and information from present day Indian media drawing on library databases including Factiva. There also may be a Harvard Business Case study to be purchased.
The course focuses on evidence-based assignments, as a part of Emory's Quality Enhancement Program (QEP). Students will gain an understanding of different types of evidence including primary and secondary sources, and how different fields may make use of evidence. Students will learn to how to evaluate the quality, credibility, reliability, and validity of different types of evidence.
